name: Dade's conjecture
summary: Dade's conjecture is a significant conjecture in finite group theory that relates the number of characters in a "block" of a finite group to the number of characters in blocks of its "p-local subgroups". Specifically, it posits a way to count and classify characters of a block by relating them to characters of blocks in certain subgroups. The conjecture was introduced by Everett C. Dade and implies other important conjectures, such as the Alperin-McKay conjecture.
head: If a finite group \(G\) has a trivial normal \(p\)-subgroup (\(O_{p}(G)=1\)) and \(B\) is a \(p\)-block of \(G\) with positive defect
tail: then the alternating sum of the number of characters with a fixed defect in related blocks of certain local subgroups is zero.Â
